quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's not like I think AI will have no impact on jobs or people. In fact, I believe that whatever AI does, currently or in the future, is up to us. It's up to the people. I do believe technology is a net positive for humanity, but I think every technology is a double-edged sword. If we're not doing the right thing as a society, as individuals, we can screw this up as well.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A human-agency framework for AI outcomes: impact isn’t predetermined—governance and individual choices shape whether benefits outweigh harms.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I chose to look at artificial intelligence through the lens of visual intelligence because humans are deeply visual animals.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A methodology for picking AI problems: anchor research direction in fundamental human capabilities to guide what to model and measure.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A single object can have infinite possibilities that is shown on an image. In order to train computers with tens and thousands of object concepts, you really need to show it millions of examples.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete scaling lesson for practitioners: real-world concept learning demands massive, diverse labeled data due to combinatorial variation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In the middle of 2015, middle of 2016, some tech companies avoid using the word AI because they were not sure if AI was a dirty word. 2017-ish was the beginning of companies calling themselves AI companies.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A specific historical data point showing how quickly market perception flipped—useful for understanding hype cycles and branding risk.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There's nothing artificial about AI. It's inspired by people. It's created by people, and most importantly, it impacts people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable human-centered framing that pushes teams to evaluate AI systems by their human origins and downstream societal effects.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Suddenly, I can involve my whole team in the design process, give feedback on design concepts really quickly and it just made the whole product development process so much more fun.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a practical collaboration loop: broaden participation and shorten feedback cycles to improve product development.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With just a few prompts, you can make any idea or design into a fully functional prototype or app that anyone can iterate on and validate with customers.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: rapidly prototype from prompts, then iterate and validate directly with customers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Stop spending so much time telling people about your product vision and instead show it to them.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Memorable guidance to communicate via tangible prototypes rather than explanations, accelerating alignment and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: My team is spread out across Colorado, Australia, Nepal, West Africa, and San Francisco.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Concrete example of a globally distributed team, underscoring real-world operational complexity practitioners may face.

quotes.topic_title: Human-centered AI optimism and responsibility
quotes.text: I'm not a utopian, so it's not like I think AI will have no impact on jobs or people. In fact, I'm a humanist. I believe that whatever AI does, currently or in the future, is up to us. It's up to the people.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A clear mental model for practitioners: AI outcomes aren’t predetermined—human choices and governance shape impact.

quotes.topic_title: Human-centered AI optimism and responsibility
quotes.text: But I think every technology is a double-edged sword, and if we're not doing the right thing as a species, as a society, as communities, as individuals, we can screw this up as well.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A cautionary framing that pushes teams to treat safety, ethics, and deployment risks as core product responsibilities.

quotes.topic_title: Human-centered AI optimism and responsibility
quotes.text: I remind them when they graduate from my lab that your field is called artificial intelligence, but there's nothing artificial about it.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that keeps practitioners focused on human origins, human values, and human consequences of AI systems.

quotes.topic_title: Human-centered AI optimism and responsibility
quotes.text: No matter which part of the AI development or AI deployment or AI application you are participating in, and most likely many of us, especially as technologists, we're in multiple points. We should act like responsible individuals and care about this. Actually, care a lot about this.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: responsibility applies across the entire lifecycle (development, deployment, application), not just “ethics teams.”

quotes.topic_title: Human-centered AI optimism and responsibility
quotes.text: I think everybody today should care about AI because it is going to impact your individual life. It is going to impact your community, it's going to impact the society and the future generation. And caring about it as a responsible person is the first, but also the most important step.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A practical prioritization: broad engagement and personal responsibility are positioned as the foundational step before technical alignment debates.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from early AI to machine learning
quotes.text: And that marriage brought a very, very critical concept into AI, which is that purely rule-based program is not going to account for the vast amount of cognitive capabilities that we imagine computers can do.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A clear mental model for why learning-based approaches are necessary beyond hand-coded rules when building real-world AI systems.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from early AI to machine learning
quotes.text: So we have to use machines to learn the patterns.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A succinct, actionable principle for practitioners: prioritize pattern-learning over brittle rule engineering for scalable capability.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from early AI to machine learning
quotes.text: For example, if you give it three cats, the hope is not just for the machines to recognize these three cats. The hope is the machines can recognize the fourth cat, the fifth cat, the sixth cat, and all the other cats.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete example that defines generalization—the core goal of machine learning—rather than memorization.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from early AI to machine learning
quotes.text: I chose to look at artificial intelligence through the lens of visual intelligence because humans are deeply visual animals.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A strategic research methodology: pick a foundational modality (vision) that anchors broader intelligence, not just language.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from early AI to machine learning
quotes.text: We can talk a little more later, but so much of our intelligence is built upon visual, perceptual, spatial understanding, not just language per se. I think they're complementary.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterbalance to language-centric AI thinking, emphasizing multimodal foundations (vision + language) for robust intelligence.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: And there was one singular pain point is that these models don't have data to be trained on.
quotes.speaker: Fei Fei
quotes.context: Highlights a practical bottleneck practitioners can audit for: model progress often stalls due to missing/insufficient training data rather than model choice.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: So I think my students and I conjectured that a very critically-overlooked ingredient of bringing AI to life is big data.
quotes.speaker: Fei Fei
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: treat data as a first-class “ingredient” (not an afterthought) when trying to make ML systems work.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: We curated very carefully, 15 million images on the internet, created a taxonomy of 22,000 concepts, borrowing other researchers' work like linguists work on WordNet, and it's a particular way of dictionarying words.
quotes.speaker: Fei Fei
quotes.context: Concrete methodology + data point: large-scale curation plus a concept taxonomy (leveraging existing ontologies) can unlock major capability gains.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: And that combination of the trio technology, big data, neural network, and GPU was kind of the golden recipe for modern AI.
quotes.speaker: Fei Fei
quotes.context: A reusable framework for practitioners: performance breakthroughs often require aligning data, model class, and compute rather than optimizing just one.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: Now, it's internet-scale data mostly texts is a much more complex neural network architecture than 2012, but it's still neural network and a lot more GPUs, but it's still GPUs.
quotes.speaker: Fei Fei
quotes.context: Counterintuitive continuity: despite architectural advances, the core scaling ingredients remain the same—useful for prioritizing investments.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a “dirty word” to mainstream branding
quotes.text: I do remember the companies, the tech companies, I am not going to name names, but I was in a conversation in one of the early days, I think is in the middle of 2015, middle of 2016, some tech companies avoid using the word AI because they were not sure if AI was a dirty word.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete example of how recently “AI” was considered risky branding—even in tech—highlighting how fast narratives can flip.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a “dirty word” to mainstream branding
quotes.text: And I remember I was actually encouraging everybody to use the word AI because to me that is one of the most audacious question humanity has ever asked in our quest for science and technology, and I feel very proud of this term.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A branding/positioning principle: own ambitious language when it reflects the true mission, rather than hiding behind safer terminology.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a “dirty word” to mainstream branding
quotes.text: 2016, I think because that was-
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Pins the “AI as a dirty word” moment to a specific year, useful for understanding the timeline of mainstream adoption.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a “dirty word” to mainstream branding
quotes.text: but I think if you look at the Silicon Valley tech companies, if you trace their marketing term, I think 2017-ish was the beginning of companies calling themselves AI companies.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A practical methodology—trace marketing language over time—to see when a technology crosses from niche to default identity.

quotes.topic_title: AI as a “dirty word” to mainstream branding
quotes.text: AI is a field of, at this point, 70 years old and we have gone through many generations. Nobody, no one could have gotten here by themselves.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterweight to “single hero” narratives: progress is multi-generational and collective, which changes how leaders should credit and build teams.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: I feel AGI is more a marketing term than a scientific term as a scientist than technologist.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Challenges practitioners to be precise about goals/definitions and not let hype-driven labels substitute for measurable scientific progress.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: Oh no, I definitely think we need more innovations.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Direct guidance that scaling alone isn’t sufficient—teams should plan for new ideas beyond more data/compute/parameters.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: Today, you take a model and run it through a video of a couple of office rooms and ask the model to count the number of chairs. And this is something a toddler could do or maybe an elementary school kid could do, and AI could not do that, right?
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Concrete example practitioners can use as a diagnostic benchmark for grounding, perception, and robust scene understanding.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: So there's just so much AI today could not do, then let alone thinking about how did someone like Isaac Newton look at the movements of the celestial bodies and derive an equation or a set of equations that governs the movement of all bodies, that level of creativity, extrapolation, abstraction. We have no way of enabling AI to do that today.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Provides a clear capability yardstick—scientific abstraction and theory-building—as a north-star test beyond benchmark performance.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: Let's give AI all the data including modern instruments data of celestial bodies, which Newton did not have, and give it to that and just ask AI to create the 17th century set of equations on the laws of bodily movements. Today's AI cannot do that.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Counterintuitive “more data isn’t enough” thought experiment that highlights limits in reasoning and discovery, not just information access.

quotes.topic_title: Why world models are the next frontier
quotes.text: Think about a very chaotic first responder scene, whether it's fire or some traffic accident or some natural disaster. And if you immerse yourself in those scene and think about how people organize themselves to rescue people, to stop further disasters, to put down fires, a lot of that is movements is spontaneous understanding of objects, worlds, human situational awareness. Language is part of that, but a lot of those situations, language cannot get you to put down the fire.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete example showing why language-only intelligence is insufficient for real-world, embodied problem-solving.

quotes.topic_title: Why world models are the next frontier
quotes.text: it dawned on me that the linchpin of connecting the additional intelligence, in addition to language embodied AI, which are robotics, connecting visual intelligence, is the sense of spatial intelligence about understanding the world.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A memorable “linchpin” framing that positions spatial intelligence as the bridge between vision, action, and robotics.

quotes.topic_title: Why world models are the next frontier
quotes.text: So world model is a foundation that you can use to reason, to interact, and to create worlds.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A crisp, practitioner-friendly definition that turns “world models” into a 3-part capability checklist (reason/interact/create).

quotes.topic_title: Why world models are the next frontier
quotes.text: I think that we shouldn't underestimate or maybe we tend not to talk about how humans, as an embodied agents, can actually benefit so much from world models and spatial intelligence models as well as robots can.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that world models aren’t only for robots—humans can be directly augmented as embodied agents too.

quotes.topic_title: World models’ applications: design, science, creativity
quotes.text: And also design, humans design from machines to buildings to homes and also scientific discovery.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Expands the application surface of world models beyond robots/games into high-value domains like design and science.

quotes.topic_title: World models’ applications: design, science, creativity
quotes.text: But with that 2D flat photo, the humans, especially two important humans, James Watson and Francis Crick, in addition to their other information, was able to reason in 3D space and deduce a highly three-dimensional double helix structure of the DNA.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Concrete example of how spatial reasoning can turn limited observations into breakthrough scientific models—an argument for AI-assisted spatial intelligence.

quotes.topic_title: World models’ applications: design, science, creativity
quotes.text: You cannot think in 2D and deduce that structure. You have to think in 3D spatial, use the human spatial intelligence.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A crisp mental model: certain discoveries require 3D “world modeling,” implying tools should explicitly support spatial reasoning.

quotes.topic_title: World models’ applications: design, science, creativity
quotes.text: So I think even in scientific discovery, spatial intelligence or AI-assisted spatial intelligence is critical.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Actionable direction for practitioners: prioritize spatial-intelligence capabilities when building AI systems for science and R&D.

quotes.topic_title: World models’ applications: design, science, creativity
quotes.text: This is such an example of, I think it was Chris Dixon that had this line that the next big thing is going to start off feeling like a toy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Contrarian product heuristic: don’t dismiss early prototypes that feel like “toys”—they may be the seed of major platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're sending marketing campaigns, verification codes, or account alerts, you need them to reach users reliably.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Highlights reliability as the core requirement for any customer-communications system across multiple message types.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 150,000 businesses, including 8 of the top 10 largest tech companies globally use Sinch's API to build messaging, email, and calling into their products.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point and example of API-driven communications embedded directly into products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of RCS as SMS2.0.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: A simple mental model for product teams to understand RCS as the next-generation evolution of SMS.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Instead of getting texts from a random number, your users will see your verified company name and logo without needing to download anything new.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Explains the practical UX/security shift of verified sender identity and zero-download adoption friction.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: US carriers are starting to adopt RCS.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Signals an ecosystem inflection point that can change messaging strategy and timing for US-focused teams.

quotes.topic_title: Robotics and the “bitter lesson” constraints
quotes.text: And Richard has said, if you look at the history, especially the algorithmic development of AI, it turns out simpler model with a ton of data always win at the end of the day instead of the more complex model with less data.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A crisp statement of Sutton’s “bitter lesson” as a practical model-selection heuristic: prioritize scale and simplicity over intricate algorithms when data can grow.

quotes.topic_title: Robotics and the “bitter lesson” constraints
quotes.text: So you have this perfect alignment between what you hope to get, which we call objective function and what your training data looks like.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Highlights an underappreciated reason LLMs scale so well—tight objective/data alignment—which practitioners can use as a diagnostic when choosing problem formulations and datasets.

quotes.topic_title: Robotics and the “bitter lesson” constraints
quotes.text: You hope to get actions out of robots, but your training data lacks actions in 3D worlds, and that's what robots have to do, right? Actions in 3D worlds.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Names the core robotics bottleneck (action-labeled 3D interaction data), guiding teams toward data strategies rather than only algorithmic tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Robotics and the “bitter lesson” constraints
quotes.text: So then we have to start talking about adding supplementing data such as teleoperation data or synthetic data so that the robots are trained with this hypothesis of bitter lesson, which is large amount of data.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Actionable prescription for robotics practitioners: close the action-data gap by augmenting web video with teleop and synthetic interaction data at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Robotics and the “bitter lesson” constraints
quotes.text: It's 20 years since that prototype of a self-driving car being able to drive 130 miles in the Nevada desert to today's Waymo and on the street of San Francisco.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete timeline/data point that sets realistic expectations for robotics productization cycles, even for “simpler” robots like cars.

quotes.topic_title: Awe at human intelligence and energy efficiency
quotes.text: We operate on about 20 watts. That's dimmer than any light bulb in the room I'm in right now. And yet we can do so much.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete energy-efficiency data point that reframes human intelligence as an engineering benchmark for AI and robotics.

quotes.topic_title: Awe at human intelligence and energy efficiency
quotes.text: So I think actually the more I work in AI, the more I respect humans.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterintuitive takeaway that doing AI research can increase appreciation for human robustness rather than diminish it.

quotes.topic_title: Awe at human intelligence and energy efficiency
quotes.text: Just the complexity just to get a machine to just walk around and not hit things and fall, does just give you more respect for what we've already got?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights embodied navigation as a deceptively hard baseline task, useful for grounding expectations about real-world AI capability.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: prompt-to-3D worlds product
quotes.text: we believe that spatial intelligence and world modeling is as important, if not more, to language models and complementary to language models.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A clear mental model for practitioners: treat world models/spatial intelligence as a first-class pillar alongside (and complementary to) LLMs.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: prompt-to-3D worlds product
quotes.text: we wanted to seize this opportunity to create deep tech research lab that can connect the dots between frontier models with products.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: An actionable product strategy: build an org explicitly designed to translate frontier research into shipped products.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: prompt-to-3D worlds product
quotes.text: We've spent a year and plus building the world's first generative model that can output genuinely 3D worlds. That's a very, very hard problem.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete milestone and expectation-setter for teams considering prompt-to-3D: “genuinely 3D” is a hard, long-horizon technical lift.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: prompt-to-3D worlds product
quotes.text: the dots that lead you into the world was an intentional feature visualization, is not part of the model. The model actually just generates the world.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product lesson: user-delighting “explainability/preview” UI can be separate from the core model and still drive perceived magic.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: prompt-to-3D worlds product
quotes.text: it was really satisfying for us to hear that this intentional visualization feature that's not just the big hardcore model actually has delighted our users.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Reinforces a practical methodology: invest in lightweight UX layers around the model to increase adoption and delight.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases and learning from users
quotes.text: So we were collaborating with those technical artists and directors, and they were saying, this has cut our production time by 40X.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Concrete performance datapoint showing how world-modeling tools can radically compress virtual production timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases and learning from users
quotes.text: One of the biggest pain point is to create synthetic data for training robots.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Highlights a core bottleneck in robotics that practitioners can target with synthetic environments and simulation.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases and learning from users
quotes.text: Otherwise, humans have to build every single asset for robots. That's just going to take a lot longer.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A clear argument for shifting from manual asset creation to scalable, computer-generated simulation pipelines.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases and learning from users
quotes.text: This is very much the way things work in AI. I've had other AI leaders on the podcast and it's always put things out there early as soon as you can to discover where the big use cases are.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical go-to-market methodology for AI products: ship early to learn real use cases from users.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases and learning from users
quotes.text: It turned out some of the psychiatric patients they study, they need to understand how their brain respond to different immersive things of different features. For example, messy scenes or clean scenes or whatever you name it.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Unexpected cross-domain application showing how controllable 3D environments enable new experimental designs in psychology.
